results.headline: 'Poseidon' Remakes a Disaster in a Caldron of Distress

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Poseidon

results.summary_short: The chief virtue of Wolfgang Petersen's reasonably well-executed remake of "The Poseidon Adventure" is that it keeps the action moving.

results.headline: In 'Mendy: A Question of Faith,' Testing One's Mettle in the Secular World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mendy: A Question of Faith

results.summary_short: At its core, Adam Vardy's "Mendy: A Question of Faith" espouses an inanely simplistic worldview, but it does so with a surprising amount of respect.

results.headline: In 'Just My Luck,' Lindsay Lohan Is a Career Girl Hunting Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Just My Luck

results.summary_short: "Just My Luck" is a bit of lukewarm cappuccino froth confected to float Lindsay Lohan to the next stage of her career.

results.headline: The Improbable Dream of a Guy Who Just Wants to Play Soccer in 'Goal!'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Goal! The Dream Begins

results.summary_short: "Goal! The Dream Begins" follows a young Mexican soccer whiz from Los Angeles to England and a tryout with Newcastle United.

results.headline: Confronting a Mayor's Legacy in 'Giuliani Time'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Giuliani Time

results.summary_short: While hardly unbiased, Kevin Keating's documentary about the former mayor of New York City is not entirely one-sided.

results.headline: In 'Sketches of Frank Gehry,' a Design for Living Large

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sketches of Frank Gehry

results.summary_short: Sydney Pollack's absorbing documentary respects the essential enigma of its subject even as it illuminates his ways of thinking about form, space and construction.

results.headline: The Show Must Go On, Even During a Coup, in 'Light From the East'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Light from the East

results.summary_short: Amy Grappell's documentary is about American actors who were accidentally caught up in momentous political events during a tour of Ukraine in 1991.

results.headline: In 'Russian Dolls,' Some Continuing Adventures of Europe's Young Suave Set

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Russian Dolls

results.summary_short: Cédric Klapisch's "Russian Dolls" has not much on its mind beyond updating the lives of the characters in his 2002 comedy "L'Auberge Espagnole."

results.headline: 'Aw Shucks' Cowpoke Rides the Range in 'Down in the Valley'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Down in the Valley

results.summary_short: An allegorical neo-Western with dreams as big as the fantasies that consume its protagonist, a suburban cowboy (Edward Norton) who is not what he appears to be.

results.headline: A Boy's Days Are Numbered, but His Desire Is Boundless in 'One Last Thing ...'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Last Thing

results.summary_short: "One Last Thing ..." is shrewdly divided against itself. What begins as a small, cleareyed drama about a teenager with terminal cancer morphs into a gauzy tear-jerker.

results.headline: The Power to Help Others Backfires for the 'Mistress of Spices'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Mistress of Spices

results.summary_short: Imagine "Like Water for Chocolate" without the passion. Such is the premise of "Mistress of Spices," Paul Mayeda Berges's film-directing debut.

results.headline: Family Ties and Australian History, Both Soaked in Blood, in 'The Proposition'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Proposition

results.summary_short: This Australian western, written by the darkly moody musician and author Nick Cave, tells a story of murder in the outback that is as cruel as it is aesthetically flamboyant.

results.headline: In Chen Kaige's 'Promise,' Waiting for Winter to Follow Spring

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Promise

results.summary_short: A lavish spectacle — somewhere between grand opera and cartoon — about a love triangle involving a general, a slave and a cursed princess.

results.headline: Swinging Is Back in 'Kiss Me Again'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kiss Me Again

results.summary_short: William Tyler Smith discovers one of the tiredest male-fantasy plotlines around: man talks gorgeous wife into agreeing to invite another woman into their bed.

results.headline: Going to Extremes and Getting Personal in 'Mission: Impossible III'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mission: Impossible III

results.summary_short: Although he slams into stationary objects with his customary zeal, Tom  Cruise is off his game here, sabotaged by a misguided attempt to shade his character with gray.

results.headline: The New Kid in Town Fights to Save an Endangered Species in 'Hoot'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hoot

results.summary_short: This sweet-natured but plodding adaptation of a young adult novel by Carl Hiaasen could have used a little less broad satire of corporate greed and a few more, well, owls.

results.headline: Mysterious Moans From an Invisible Ghost in 'An American Haunting'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of An American Haunting

results.summary_short: Things go bump in the night in this 19th-century  ghost story, but it's the bump of emptying seats, as audiences flee in boredom, that will haunt you for days.

results.headline: A Farmer at Odds With the Old South in 'Crazy Like a Fox'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crazy Like A Fox

results.summary_short: Roger Rees abandons dignity — though not his native English accent — to play Nat Banks, the proud but impoverished owner of a decrepit Virginia farm.

results.headline: Majoring in Caricature in 'Art School Confidential'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Art School Confidential

results.summary_short: Terry Zwigoff and Daniel Clowes plod through a grouchy attack on — and example of — the pretense and hypocrisy of self-declared artists.

results.headline: Siblings Trapped in a Loud and Messy Crossfire in 'How I Killed a Saint'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How I Killed a Saint

results.summary_short: Filmed in a covert, voyeuristic style, "How I Killed a Saint" successfully conveys the pervasive anxiety of a country teetering on the brink of civil war.
